Aoshima (1951) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Inonotus Obliquus | capShape = no | whichGills = NA | hymeniumType = smooth | ecologicalType = parasitic | howEdible = caution | sporePrintColor = | stipeCharacter = NA }} '''''Inonotus obliquus''''', commonly known as '''chaga''' (a [[Latinisation (literature)|Latinisation]] of the Russian word чага), is a [[fungus]] in the family [[Hymenochaetaceae]]. It is [[parasitism|parasitic]] on [[birch]] and other trees. The sterile [[Polypore|conk]] is irregularly formed and has the appearance of burnt charcoal. It is not the [[sporocarp (fungi)|fruiting body]] of the fungus, but a [[sclerotium]] or mass of [[mycelium]], mostly black because of the presence of massive amounts of [[melanin]].{{Cite journal|last=Babitskaya|first=VG|last2=Shcherba|first2=VV|last3=Lkonnikova|first3=NV |date=2000|title=Melanin complex of the fungus Inonotus obliquus|journal=Appl Biochem Microbiol|volume=36|issue=4|pages=377–381|doi=10.1007/BF02738046}} Some people consider '''chaga''' to be medicinal, though this is subject to debate as it has not been tested in human clinical trials and there are potential hazards from its consumption. ''I. obliquus'' is found most commonly in the [[Circumboreal Region]] of the Northern Hemisphere, where it is distributed in birch forests.{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Min-Woong|last2=Hur|first2=Hyeon|last3=Chang|first3=Kwang-Choon|last4=Lee|first4=Tae-Soo|last5=Ka|first5=Kang-Hyeon|last6=Jankovsky|first6=L.|date=December 2008|title=Introduction to Distribution and Ecology of Sterile Conks of Inonotus obliquus|journal=Mycobiology|volume=36|issue=4|pages=199–202|doi=10.4489/MYCO.2008.36.4.199|issn=1229-8093|pmc=3755195|pmid=23997626}} == Morphology == [[File:Inonotus obliquus, Finland.jpg|thumb|Chaga on a birch tree]] [[File:Chaga in alder.jpg|thumb|Chaga in alder]] [[File:Chaga fruiting body sample.png|thumb|150px|Chaga fruiting body from a dead birch tree]] [[File:Chaga-development.png|thumb|180px|Birch slices showing the development of chaga]] ''I. obliquus'' causes a white [[heart rot]] to develop in the host tree. The chaga spores enter the tree through wounds, particularly poorly healed branch stubs. The white rot decay will spread throughout the [[Wood|heartwood]] of the host. During the infection cycle, penetration of the [[Wood|sapwood]] occurs only around the sterile exterior [[mycelium]] mass. The chaga fungus will continue to cause decay within the living tree for 10–80+ years. While the tree is alive, only sterile mycelial masses are produced (the black exterior conk). The sexual stage begins after the tree, or some portion of the tree, is killed by the infection. ''I. obliquus'' will begin to produce fertile fruiting bodies underneath the bark. These bodies begin as a whitish mass that turn to brown with time. Since the sexual stage occurs almost entirely under the bark, the fruiting body is rarely seen.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/inonotus_obliquus.html|title=Inonotus obliquus (MushroomExpert.Com)|last=MushroomExpert.Com|website=www.mushroomexpert.com|access-date=2017-08-15}} These fruiting bodies produce [[basidiospore]]s which will spread the infection to other vulnerable trees. == Common names == The name ''chaga'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|tʃ|ɑː|ɡ|ə|}} ) comes from the Russian name of the fungus ([[wikt:transliterate|transliterated]] from ''чага''), which in turn is purportedly derived from the word for the fungus in [[Komi-Permyak language|Komi-Permyak]], the language of the [[indigenous peoples]] in the [[Kama River|Kama River Basin]], west of the [[Ural Mountains]]. It is also known as the clinker polypore (from its resemblance to the slag left after a coal fire, known commonly as a "[[wikt:clinker|clinker]]" when coal fires were common), cinder [[Polypore|conk]], black mass and birch canker polypore.{{cite web| last = Needham| first = Arthur| title = Clinker Polypore, Chaga| date = 2005-12-16| url = http://www.sierrapotomac.org/W_Needham/ClinkerPolypore_Chaga_051216.htm| accessdate = 10 October 2011| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110909150937/http://sierrapotomac.org/W_Needham/ClinkerPolypore_Chaga_051216.htm| archive-date = 9 September 2011| url-status = dead| df = dmy-all}} In [[England]] and officially in Canada, it is known as the sterile conk trunk rot of birch.{{Cite web|url=https://tidcf.nrcan.gc.ca/en/diseases/factsheet/1000010|title=Sterile conk trunk rot of birch|publisher=Canadian Forest Service, Natural Resources Canada, Government of Canada |language=en|date=4 August 2015|accessdate=15 August 2017}} In North America, it is commonly referred to by its Russian name, chaga. In France, it is called the ''carie blanche spongieuse de bouleau'' (spongy white birch tree rot), and in Germany it is known as ''Schiefer Schillerporling'' (oblique ''Inonotus''). The Dutch name is ''berkenweerschijnzwam'' (birch glow mushroom). In [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]], the name is ''kreftkjuke'' which literally translates as "cancer polypore", referring to the fungus' appearance or to its alleged medicinal properties. In [[Finnish language|Finnish]], the name is ''pakurikääpä''.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} ==Distribution and cultivation== Generally found growing on birch (''[[Birch|Betula]]'' spp.) trees, it has also been found on alder (''[[Alder|Alnus]]'' spp.), beech (''[[Beech|Fagus]]'' spp.), oak (''[[Oak|Quercus]]'' spp.) and poplar (''[[Populus]]'' spp.).{{Cite book|title=European polypores. Part 1.|last=Ryvarden L, Gilbertson RL|publisher=Fungiflora-Fungiflora|year=1993|isbn=|location=Oslo|pages=1–387}} In species other than birch, the fungus often appears as buried stem canker, instead of the charcoal-like mass found on birch trees.{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} Attempts at [[fungiculture|cultivating]] this fungus on [[potato dextrose agar]] and other simulated [[growth medium|mediums]] resulted in a reduced and markedly different production of metabolites.{{cite journal |vauthors=Zheng W, Miao K, Liu Y, Zhao Y, Zhang M, Pan S, etal | title=Chemical diversity of biologically active metabolites in the sclerotia of ''Inonotus obliquus'' and submerged culture strategies for up-regulating their production | journal=Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology | year= 2010 | volume= 87 | issue= 4 | pages= 1237–54 | pmid=20532760 | doi=10.1007/s00253-010-2682-4}} Cultivated chaga developed a reduced number of [[phytosterol]]s, particularly [[lanosterol]], an intermediate in the synthesis of [[ergosterol]] and [[lanostane]]-type [[triterpene]]s.{{Cite journal | last1 = Zheng | first1 = W. F. | last2 = Liu | first2 = T. | last3 = Xiang | first3 = X. Y. | last4 = Gu | first4 = Q. | title = Sterol composition in field-grown and cultured mycelia of ''Inonotus obliquus'' | journal = Yao Xue Xue Bao = Acta Pharmaceutica Sinica | volume = 42 | issue = 7 | pages = 750–756 |date=July 2007 | pmid = 17882960 }} ==Chemistry== The black [[sclerotium]] has been shown to contain large concentrations of melanin.{{Cite journal|last=Babitskaya|first=VG|last2=Shcherba|first2=VV|last3=Lkonnikova|first3=NV|last4=Bisko|first4=NA|last5=Mitropolskaya|first5=NY|date=2002|title=Melanin complex from medicinal mushroom ''Inonotus obliquus'' (Pers: Fr) Pilát (chaga) (Aphyllophoromyceditdeae)|journal=Int J Med Mushrooms|volume=4|pages=139–145}}{{Cite journal|last=Lee| first=JH|last2=Hyun|first2=CK|date=September 2014| title=Insulin-sensitizing and beneficial lipid-metabolic effects of the water-soluble melanin complex extracted from ''Inonotus obliquus''|journal=Phytother Res|volume=28|issue=9| pages=1320–1328|doi=10.1002/ptr.5131|pmid=24615848}} Chaga has been reported to contain extremely high concentrations of [[oxalate]], 2800-11200 mg total oxalates/100 g sclerotium, one of the highest reported levels of any organism.{{Cite journal|last=Kikuchi| first=Y|last2=Seta|first2=K|first3=Ogawa|last3=Y|last4=Takayama| first4=T|last5=Nagata| first5=M|last6=Taguchi| first6=T|last7=Yahata| first7=k|display-authors=3|date=June 2014| title=Chaga mushroom-induced oxalate nephropathy|journal=Clin Nephrol|volume=81|issue=6| pages=440–444|doi=10.5414/CN107655|pmid=23149251}} ==Preparation== {{medical citations needed|section|date=January 2018}} Chaga is traditionally grated into a fine powder and used to brew a beverage resembling [[coffee]] or [[tea]]. However, caution is warranted with chronic use due to the extremely high concentrations of oxalates in chaga. Currently, three extraction processes are used. * Hot water extraction is the most common and the cheapest method. The ß-D-glucans may have a content of approximately 35% in a pure extract.{{Cite journal | last1 = Rhee | first1 = S.Y. | title = A comparative study of analytical methods for alkali-soluble β-glucan in medicinal mushroom, Chaga (Inonotus obliquus) | journal = LWT - Food Science and Technology | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | pages = 545–549 | year = 2008 | doi=10.1016/j.lwt.2007.03.028 }} * [[Ethanol]] or [[methanol]] extraction isolates the water-insoluble components, betulinic acid, betulin and the phytosterols. This extraction process is in general used as a second step after hot-water extraction, since ethanol alone will not break down [[chitin]] effectively - heat is essential. * [[Fermentation (food)|Fermentation]] is the most time-consuming and most expensive. Because fermentation methods are not standardized (many types of bacteria and fungi can be used in the process), the outcome is also not standardized. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} * [[Herbalism]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Medicinal herbs & fungi}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1956937}} [[Category:Fungi described in 1801]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Inonotus]] [[Category:Medicinal fungi]]
